content: {{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-233-04-A |Item_parent=Valvulopathies |Item_parent_short=Valvulopathies |Rank=A |Title=Knowing the functional signs and clinical examination (auscultation) of MI, RA, IA, MR |Description=None |Topic=Positive diagnosis |Contributors=Myriam Akodad,Florence Leclercq |Order=4}} '''Mitral insufficiency''' : * Functional signs: ** Acute MI: '''acute dyspnoea''/OAP, snapping and brief '''chest pain''' for cord rupture (rare). ** Chronic MI: asymptomatic for a long time, then progressive dyspnoea. * Auscultation: ** Soft, steam-jet murmur, holosystolic if severe, predominant at the mitral focus, radiating into the left axilla. ** Protodiastolic gallop in severe MI and B2 burst if associated pulmonary hypertension. * Left heart failure or OAP (sometimes unilateral in case of cord rupture). Aortic stenosis: asymptomatic for a long time * Functional signs: symptoms on exertion (''dyspnoea+++, angina++,'' syncope or lipothymia) * Auscultation: raspy, meso-systolic murmur, predominant in the aortic focus, radiating to the carotid arteries, abolition of B2 (in the case of a tight RA). * Left heart failure: poor prognosis Aortic insufficiency: asymptomatic for a long time * Functional signs: Dyspnoea+++, exertional angina. * ''Auscultation'': protodiastolic murmur, soft, aspirative, aortic focus radiating along the left edge of the sternum, better heard if the patient is seated. In severe AI: holodiastolic murmur, diastolic Flint roll, gallop, pistol-shot, etc. * Peripheral signs: peripheral hyperpulsatility and increase in differential BP due to a fall in diastolic pressure (< 50 mmHg = severe AI). * Left heart failure'' (late) Mitral stenosis: asymptomatic for a long time, may be revealed by pregnancy or transition to AF * Functional signs: dyspnoea, asthenia, palpitations. * Auscultation: mitral focus diastolic rolling, B1 burst if valve is flexible, B2 splitting if PAH (Durozier 3-step rhythm) * Left and right heart failure, AF, signs of pulmonary hypertension, haemoptysis.

question.question: Which of the following is a characteristic auscultation finding in severe mitral insufficiency?
question.option_a: A soft, steam-jet murmur, holosystolic if severe, predominant at the mitral focus, radiating into the left axilla.
question.option_b: A raspy, meso-systolic murmur, predominant in the aortic focus, radiating to the carotid arteries.
question.option_c: A protodiastolic rolling, B1 burst if valve is flexible, B2 splitting if PAH.
question.option_d: A protodiastolic murmur, soft, aspirative, aortic focus radiating along the left edge of the sternum.
